page.title: 15LANDSCAPE
page.content: The{houses and cottages}in the village are mainly stone and slate and are clustered around two areas of grass. The centre green has an impressive sycamore. The dwellings are, in the main, grouped in terraces. Some of the houses have a lancet window at first floor level with a matching fanlight over the door. This is typical of Victorian architecture and is from the days when Rosedale was an important ironstone mining area. Some of the remains of the old mines and railway track may still be seen. The Bow Bridge at the foot of Chimney Bank,(1:3) is 17th.Century. {The National Park Committee}is the local planning authority and aims to protect the attractive features such as the buildings, building patterns, trees and open spaces which go to make up the character of the place.
